blog/master-as-the-needle.title: master as the needle - blog series
blog/master-as-the-needle.content:
intro and motivation


I donâ€™t feel accomplished when I vibe code, â€œhe who does the work gets the learningâ€ and if I outsource all / most of it then Iâ€™m not actually becoming a more capable person when I have Claude write all my code, and I think thatâ€™s not good.


Instead, I had the thought that I can LLMâ€™s to write code for my projects, get something that works, then go back through and come to understand why the code is working and what itâ€™s doing under the hood.


Relatedly, Iâ€™ve seen some job applications that say theyâ€™re fine with people using AI tools to write code in interviews, but the interviewer will also test whether the applicant actually understands whatâ€™s being written. If thatâ€™s a make or break it, then Iâ€™d like to prevent myself from breaking it, which is also helpful if the LLM isnâ€™t able to replace programmers yet; you may need to visit the trenches from time to time!


And so, I decided I would 1. use LLMâ€™s to (help) create different projects Iâ€™m working on and 2. go back through to understand what it was that made the code work at all. Ideally, this should make me a better developer as well, in the least to understand on an intuitive level and be able to use that to better prompt models in the future.


In the â€œBook of Five Ringsâ€, Miyamoto Musashi mentions the phrase â€œThe master as the needle, the student as the thread.â€ As Iâ€™d never heard this before, I looked around and the best explanation I found was saying how:

The master will guide the student through the terrain of the problem (like a needle)
But the student has to do the actual work by providing the strength needed for a solution to work (like the thread).

the master will no longer be necessary, but the student remains while keeping the structure together.





In this way, I become the thread and come out on the other side understanding better how the machine works.


This is a series of experiments in this vein where Iâ€™ll detail how I built different projects and what I learned in the post-mortem, complete with prompts, facts, and other tidbits that will help your own journey.


the solution relies on the strength of the student to support the residual structure
the master as the needle
â€œTell me and Iâ€™ll forget, show me Iâ€™ll remember, involve me and Iâ€™ll understand.â€
Thereâ€™s a critical line between technological capability and genuine understanding, can you truly comprehend something without wrestling with its complexity? The phrase â€˜those who do the work receive the learningâ€™ is more than a platitude; itâ€™s a commitment to technologically influenced thinking, where AI becomes a tool for insight, not a replacement for understanding.
the core learning strategy
My approach is simple, and deliberate: use LLMs to generate working code for projects, and then dive deep to understand why and how that code works under the hood.
In the â€œBook of Five Ringsâ€, Miyamoto Musashi mentions the phrase â€œThe master as the needle, the student as the thread.â€ The consensus Iâ€™ve found on what this means goes:

The master guides the student through the terrain of a problem (like a needle)
The student provides solution and uses their strenth to support it (like the thread)
Ultimately, the master becomes unnecessary, but the student remains, holding the structure together

In this way, I aim to have LLMs be my needle and have myself become the thread, learning to support the structures Iâ€™m working with.
what to expect in this series
This blog series is an experiment in active, intentional learning. Each post will be a deep dive into a specific project:

How the project was conceived
Initial AI-assisted code generation
Code review with detailed exploration of key concepts
Personal reflections and learning moments
Practical insights for other learners

This series is a live experiment in understanding; deliberately messy, intentionally iterative, and perpetually evolving. Not to continually be seeking perfection, but instead persistent curiosity.

blog/zk-proof-intro.title: quick thoughts on zk proof foundations
blog/zk-proof-intro.content:
~~ A friendly exploration of zero-knowledge proof basics through dialogue ~~ 
Intro
I like holding hands. This is a hand-holding post on the basic ideas of what makes zero-knowledge proofs work.
Dialogue
Person A: So like, what are they?
Person B: Zero knowledge proof (ZKP), itâ€™s a way to convince another person that something is true, but you donâ€™t need to show proof of it (or to have â€œzero knowledgeâ€ of what makes something true).
Person A: What?
Person B: Yeah I know.
Person A: But how?
Person B: Well to start, I think that (with ZKPâ€™s) saying that â€œI have proof this is true!â€ is actually a bad word to use. We donâ€™t have proof! Instead, itâ€™s better to say â€œthis thing is probably trueâ€.
Person A: â€¦

âš ï¸ Key Concept
Zero-knowledge proofs are about probability, not absolute certainty.

Person B: Quick background; thereâ€™s two people in this equation, a prover (the one saying â€œbelieve me!â€) and the verifier (the one saying, â€œbut how do I actually know?â€). The prover wants the verifier to believe them, but doesnâ€™t want to give out some type of information. (letâ€™s just say the prover doesnâ€™t want to share their birthdate, but wants to go a club; they need to prove that theyâ€™re over 21.)
Person A: Ok, prover needs to prove that theyâ€™re over 21, but doesnâ€™t want to show their birthday.
Person B: Yup. Keep in mind that your proof will either equal â€œtrue or falseâ€ (like, youâ€™re over 21 or not)
Person A: Great
Person B: Great
Person A: But wait, proof = true or false, but you said itâ€™s better to say â€œprobably trueâ€?
Person B: Ya, so what happens with some fancy computer magic is the verifier (the one saying â€œcan I actually believe the prover?â€) will give a bunch of True/False tests to the prover. These tests basically say (in computer terms) â€œok, if you actually were over 21, then you should pass this random test!â€ The prover can now 1. either guess correctly each time (which sounds hard to do maybe), or they 2. actually are over 21 and you can pass the test.
Person A: But wouldnâ€™t the answer just be â€œyesâ€ each time? That seems pretty easy to hack
Person B: Yeah that would, so they change it up a bit. But basically, if you have the ground truth, that you are over 21, itâ€™s easy to answer correctly. If you donâ€™t, you just have to guess. You have to guess right every time they ask you a question
Person A: ğŸ˜²ğŸ˜¯ğŸ˜®
Person B: â€¼ï¸ğŸ¤¯ğŸ˜µ
Person A: Each time?
Person B: Ya, imagine having to guess correctly a whole bunch of times, and if you mess up once, youâ€™re done kiddo. And these guys like math, hereâ€™s how you calculate the probability:

ğŸ“Š The Math of Certainty
With each additional test, the probability of successfully guessing drops dramatically:

1 test: 50% chance of guessing correctly
2 tests: 25% chance
3 tests: 12.5% chance
And so onâ€¦


Person A: Oh my
Person B: And this is also where â€œprobably trueâ€ comes in. If someone guessed it right once, thatâ€™s only 50% chance (true/false). But what if they had to get it right twice? Thatâ€™s 25% (50% x 50%). Three times? 12.5%.
Person A: And it just keeps going down?
Person B: Yup, put into your calculator (1/2)^{the number of tests youâ€™d give}. (first try the above numbers, noting that you have to move the decimal two places to the right to get percentages like above. (1/2)^1 = .5 , but move it two and youâ€™ve got 50%)
Intermission!!
You should actually plug some numbers into the calculator to see how quickly the number goes down. Ask yourself this, if you were the verifier, what would your acceptable percentage be? How small of a chance would you accept of some rando correctly guessing each of your tests? How small does it have to be to accept that guessing correctly probably didnâ€™t happen?
Back to the show
Person A: Wow, ten tests gives a 0.0976562% of someone guessing correctly, or 1/1024 chance of getting it right.
Person B: Crazy right!? And now again imagine yourself as the verifier (the person checking IDs). At what percentage do you say that youâ€™re convinced? Is a 9% possibility that a person is lying an â€œacceptable risk to take? The actual percentage is something fun to think about, but the more important thing is to realize that the verifier actually never sees the evidence of whether or not someone is lying, but instead the verifier sees a low enough probability that theyâ€™re not lying and then they are convinced that thereâ€™s no lying taking place. And also, if youâ€™re not satisfied, you can just ask for more tests (it just takes a bit longer for the calculations to be checked).
Person A: Ohhhhh

ğŸ’¡ The Zero-Knowledge Part
The verifier becomes convinced without ever seeing the actual proof or private information!

Person B: Yeahhhhhhh. And just to wrap it up: the verifier never actually knows that the prover is telling the truth (this is a zero knowledge proof). The verifier is just convinced at some point that the prover is telling the truth.
